Award.AwardTitle: Properties and Behavior of Transformation Interfaces in Metal Alloys
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY: The purpose of this research is to understand the dynamic behavior, electron states, and interfacial energies of important transformation interfaces in metal alloys. The proposed research will concentrate on two types of interfaces that are still largely unexplored, and therefore, offer considerable opportunity to discover new fundamental scientific phenomena regarding their behavior. These are the solid-liquid interface, which will be investigated using Al-Si base alloy powder particles, and incoherent interphase boundaries, which will be investigated using massive transformation interfaces in Mn-Al(-C) alloys. Some specific questions that will be addressed in the proposed research are: i) Does equilibrium segregation occur at solid-liquid interfaces, can it be predicted from thermodynamics, and does it precede nucleation of a new phase at the interface? ii) Do faceted crystals present their slowest-growing interfaces during growth and their fastest-growing interfaces during dissolution as theory suggests? iii) How do interfacial fluctuations that are observed at interfaces between solid Si and solid Al and liquid Al-Si alloy occur, and how do they compare quantitatively with each other and with computer simulations? iv) How do atoms and electrons behave in liquid Al and Al-Si alloys as the liquids are undercooled in terms of the core and valence electron states, and is ordering in the liquid revealed in these properties? v) Do solid-liquid interface plasmons exist and if so, what are their properties? vi) Do low-index interfaces (e.g. {111}) form during the massive transformation for the same reasons as for grain boundaries? vii) Do {111} random grain boundaries and incoherent massive interfaces both migrate by the movement of atomic steps parallel to the {111} facet? These problems will be answered using a combination of in-situ analytical transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and other complementary experimental and computational techniques.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY: The nature of the solid-liquid interface is extremely important both scientifically and technologically. For example, almost all engineering metal alloys, such as those found in automobiles, jet engines and construction beams, start as a liquid mixture that changes into a solid at the solid-liquid interface on cooling. Likewise, the silicon wafers that are the basis of computer technology are large single-crystals that are grown from a liquid melt. In spite of the importance of the solid-liquid interface in these processes, there are few experimental data available that directly show how the different elements in the liquid mixture partition into the solid and liquid phases at the solid-liquid interface. This research will show precisely how this occurs. Another important technological interface that forms between two crystalline solids is called an incoherent interface. This type of interface is also found in almost all useful engineering metals such as those mentioned above, in the form of random grain and interphase boundaries. Knowledge of the properties of such interfaces and how they behave during metal processing is limited, but this research will reveal these phenomena. In summary, this research will generate entirely new information about important technological solid-liquid and solid-solid interfaces, thereby enhancing our ability to control such interfaces to make better engineering materials that are used throughout society. The results of this research will be widely disseminated by making the in-situ microscope videos obtained during the work available online, so that faculty, students and researchers will be able to observe the videos and use them to further their understanding and teaching of interface science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this research was to understand the dynamic behavior, electron states, and interfacial energies of important transformation interfaces in metal alloys. The proposed research concentrated on two types of interfaces that were still largely unexplored and offered opportunity to discover new fundamental scientific phenomena regarding their behavior; namely, the solid-liquid interface and incoherent interfaces. We had a number of important findings regarding the solid-liquid interface and some of these are summarized below. We were not successful in our work on incoherent interfaces and so this work is not described further.

Intellectual Merit: In terms of the solid-liquid interface, we found a new type of segregation behavior to interfaces by observing a partially molten Al-Cu-Mg-Si alloy in the transmission electron microscope (TEM). We observed the formation of transient crystalline Cu islands that come and go on the solid-liquid interface with time. We were able to obtain the orientation relationship between the Cu islands and crystalline Si at the interface from high-resolution TEM images, and compare these theories of interfacial structure (see Figure 1). These metastable Cu islands appeared to serve as a precursor phase for nucleating equilibrium theta-phase precipitates in the alloy with subsequent further cooling. This multilayer dynamic segregation behavior is not like anything that has been previously seen or predicted. In terms of broader impact, these findings provide new insight into mechanisms of segregation and nucleation that can potentially occur in all types of materials and interfaces. We also performed a number of in-situ electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS) TEM studies at the solid-liquid interface and one of the most significant findings was the observation and quantification of an interfacial plasmon between solid Si and liquid Al-alloy (see Figure 2). In terms of broader impact, nanoplasmonics is an important emerging research area and the unique plasmon resonance observed at the solid-liquid interface in our research provides insight into the potential behavior of plasmons at other solid-liquid interfaces, ranging from biomedical imaging to liquid crystals, for example. We also were able to follow changes in the electron density, density of states, and nearest-neighbor distances of atoms in the liquid Al alloy s a function of supercooling and found many new unexpected and non-linear behaviors in terms of all of these behaviors.

Broader Impact: In total, 14 archival journal papers, 6 books or conference proceedings, and 4 conference papers, were published under this grant by the principal investigator and his students and collaborators. In addition, a website was started to archive video files from in-situ studies obtained in the TEM and other electron microscopes, with brief descriptions, so that these informative dynamic studies can be accessed by students and professors world-wide to directly see how materials behave during transformation, straining, etc. The initial website can be accessed at: http://www.virginia.edu/ms/people/faculty/howe.html. As mentioned above, the unique plasmon resonance and mechanisms of segregation observed at the solid-liquid interface in our research may be generally applicable to other research areas involving solid-liquid interfaces, ranging from biomedical imaging to semiconductor growth, for example.
